abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Mulanje Mountain
            Biodiversity Conservation Project for Malawi were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            future operations should consider a Monitoring and
            Evaluation (M&E) system critical for planning and also
            as an early-warning system for management. As previously
            mentioned, this Project's ecological monitoring system
            was delayed and unable to fully inform management decisions.
            The artificial regeneration studies also show some trends
            that can be of use in the consideration for the planting of
            the species. Lessons learnt from these studies have been
            applied on the Lichenya Plateau where seedlings planted
            under canopy have shown a 95 percent rate of survival. Local
            community involvement was a critical element in ensuring
            progress toward achieving the Project's Global
            Environmental Objectives (GEOs). Provision of viable
            livelihood alternatives, coupled with pro-active engagement
            of local communities in Reserve management work and mountain
            conservation activities were essential ingredients affording
            Mulanje Mountain Conservation Trust (MMCT) and Forest
            Department (FD) the success witnessed in several of the
            Project's investments.
